awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Integrated He-CO2-N2 Isotope and Petrologic Study of Volatiles Cycling via the New Zealand Subduction System
awd_abstract_narration:
Knowledge of the cycling of volatiles such as water (H2O), carbon dioxide (CO2), and molecular N (N2) at Earth's convergent margins is fundamental to understanding the role of fluids in a variety of processes related to plate tectonics on Earth. In order to fully assess the impacts of human-related ("anthropogenic") processes on our surface environment (atmosphere, oceans, and biosphere), we must understand the natural (non-anthropogenic) processes contributing to environmental change, at all time scales. There is no better example of this need than that relating to the buildup of CO2 in the atmosphere and its likely effect on global mean surface temperature and the myriad other related processes (change in ocean surface water temperature, ocean circulation, polar ice melting, etc.). Understanding these processes is predicated on a quantitative assessment of the mass balance of volatiles entering subduction zones versus the fraction returned to the surface in fore-arc, volcanic front, or back-arc localities, versus the proportion transported into the deeper Earth (to depths greater than 150 km, in the mantle). Huge uncertainties on flux estimates of volatiles returned directly to the surface versus those subducted to the deeper mantle remain, and prevent assessments of both long- and short-term cycling histories of key volatiles between Earth's interior and external reservoirs.

In this study, the research team will investigate the cycling of volatiles in the well-characterized New Zealand North Island subduction system where input and output fluxes of specific volatiles (CO2, N2, and noble gases such as He and Ar) can be well constrained. The proposed study area, a combination of the Hikurangi Margin, Axial Ranges, Taupo Volcanic Zone and Hauraki Rift Zone, comprises a forearc-volcanic front-backarc profile providing a crucial test of the mass balance of these key volatiles between sedimentary and oceanic lithosphere inputs at the Hikurangi Trench to output via magmatic, geothermal and groundwater activity in various tectonic regimes of the North Island. The volatile input characteristics will be constrained using sediment cores from ODP Site 1124, DSDP Site 317, and an upcoming IODP leg, whereas output volatile characteristics and fluxes will be provided by extensive on-shore sampling of ~100 sites at strategically-placed localities throughout the North Island. The approach will be underpinned by thermodynamic modeling of slab volatile release utilizing Perple_X and other software and composite profiles of incoming sediment/basement. Taken together, the combination of combined petrologic-geochemical-geothermal approaches at the NZ subduction zone offers the tantalizing prospect of providing well-constrained solutions to the question of recycling efficiencies for key volatiles through subduction systems, and a clearer understanding of fundamental processes (e.g., slab composition, P-T regime, plate-coupling and upper plate structure) involved in controlling subducted volatile release/retention properties.

por.por_cntn:
This project has blended the expertise of field geologists, geophysicists, volcanologists, modelers, and geochemists in an effort to understand the deep-Earth cycling of "volatiles" such as carbon dioxide, water, and nitrogen. The work was conducted on the Hikurangi margin, where an oceanic plate is being underthrusted (subducted) beneath the North Island of New Zealand. Work such as this is key for understanding modern and long-term efficiencies of the deep cycling of these volatiles, in part to result in potentially explosive arc magmatism such as that occuring in the Taupo Volcanic Zone on the North Island.

The unusually broad perspective we've taken, in this novel, highly multidisciplinary study, has revealed some extremely important factors dictating the subduction-zone cycling of volatiles, for example, better defining the flux of carbon dioxide into Earth's atmosphere. We estimate that the Hikurangi margin, considered the home to a potential supervolcano (capable of significantly affecting Earth's climate), is currently responsible for about 2.2% of the carbon dioxide currently emitted globally from subaerial volcanoes into the atmosphere. Using a combination of carbon and helium isotope data, we have been able to constrain the proportions of this carbon dioxide produced from subducted seafloor sediment, oceanic crust, and hydrated and carbonated lithospheric mantle. Our work on gases emitted from shallow parts of the margin (on the East Coast of the North Island), together with our thermal and thermodynamic modeling, yields constraints regarding release and mobility of fluids in underthrusted sediment, relevant to consideration of the generation of earthquakes at depths up to about 50 kilometers. The Hikurangi margin is well-known as producing some extremely devastating earthquakes, for example the 2016 Kaikoura earthquake (magnitude 7.8).

The project is also highly international, involving scientists from the USA, New Zealand, and Japan, and has supported the research of several graduate students at Lehigh University and one student at University California, San Diego (the work constituted a large part of the Ph.D. dissertation of Gabe Epstein). At Lehigh University, the evolution of the study and its results have been reported to undergraduate and graduate students - a part of this presentation has involved an accounting of the ways in which events such as a global pandemic, and personnel struggles, can impact a science project (the human component of scientific research). Due to these factors, a project with an initial three-year funding period was conducted over six years. As a part of this presentation to students, we explored the science beyond the tragic eruption of Whakaari (White Island) in December, 2019. We'd been on the island sampling gases just earlier that year and, since that eruption it's been impossible to return for further sampling and monitoring of gas outputs.

Our most recent work has involved some final gas sampling, then shipping samples to the University of Tokyo for noble gas isotope analyses. The project will certainly continue beyond the funding period of this grant, with continued sampling and isotope analyses by this international group of scientists.
